articles.description:
Insufficient progress towards climate goals is slowing down the global fight against poverty, hunger and deadly diseases, according to a report released on Thursday by the UN World Meteorological Organization (WMO).

Read the full story, “Climate inaction puts lives on the line: WMO”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Climate inaction puts lives on the line: WMO

articles.description:
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Sep 13 (IPS) - On 26 August, Gabon went through the motions of an election. Official results were announced four days later, in the middle of the night, with the country under curfew. Predictably, incumbent President Ali Bongo, in power since the death of his father and predecessor in 2009, was handed a third term. Fraud allegations were rife, as in previous elections. But this time something unprecedented happened: less than an hour later the military had taken over, and the Bongo family’s 56-year reign had ended.

Read the full story, “Gabon: The End of a Dictatorship and the Beginning of Another?”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Gabon: The End of a Dictatorship and the Beginning of Another?

articles.description:
GWADAR, Pakistan, Sep 13 (IPS) - Ten years ago I ran an academy for girls in Dohr Gatti, a small slum on the outskirts of Gwadar, a coastal city in Balochistan, southwestern Pakistan. Most of the girls were between the ages of eleven and fifteen and had the little opportunity to receive a formal education.

Read the full story, “The Baloch Girls Remain Stranded at the School Gates”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: The Baloch Girls Remain Stranded at the School Gates

articles.description:
BUDGAM, INDIA, Sep 13 (IPS) - It has been over a decade since 32-year-old Rafiqa (not her real name) was sold to a villager after being lured by the promise that she would be employed in the handicrafts industry of Indian-administered Kashmir.

Read the full story, “Human Trafficking: Women Lured by Promise of Jobs, Sold as Brides”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Human Trafficking: Women Lured by Promise of Jobs, Sold as Brides

articles.description:
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Sep 13 (IPS) - The commodity boom early this century was mainly driven by mineral prices. Yet, mining’s contribution to developing countries’ revenue has been modest, largely due to massive tax evasion and avoidance.

Read the full story, “Enhancing Mining Revenue”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Enhancing Mining Revenue

articles.description:
OAKLAND, California, Sep 13 (IPS) - In the wake of the recent Africa Climate Summit, which convened in Nairobi from September 4-6, 2023, the world’s attention was drawn to the pressing challenges facing the African continent as it grapples with the devastating effects of climate change.

Read the full story, “The Africa Climate Summit: Anti-Colonial Rhetoric Meets Green Colonialism”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: The Africa Climate Summit: Anti-Colonial Rhetoric Meets Green Colonialism

articles.description:
With tens of millions of children heading back to school in recent weeks, for some, the return to class has them fearing for their lives.

Read the full story, “UN marks International Day to Protect Education with call to action”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: UN marks International Day to Protect Education with call to action

articles.description:
Both Sudanese Government forces (SAF) and their rival Rapid Support Forces (RSF) are responsible for abhorrent rights violations as they battle for supremacy, the UN envoy to the country said on Wednesday.

Read the full story, “Sudan: UN ‘will never stay neutral’ amid war and human rights abuses”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Sudan: UN ‘will never stay neutral’ amid war and human rights abuses

articles.description:
The UN system is providing aid to areas in eastern Libya impacted by the weekend floods and a disaster assessment team has been deployed to support government response and relief operations, the UN said on Wednesday.

Read the full story, “Libya floods: UN providing aid as disaster response team deploys”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Libya floods: UN providing aid as disaster response team deploys

articles.description:
Today “peace is under assault” across communities, countries and regions, UN Secretary-General António Guterres said on Wednesday, underscoring the need for global solidarity and mutual trust.

Read the full story, “Peace our ‘most fundamental job’, says Guterres”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Peace our ‘most fundamental job’, says Guterres

articles.description:
A string of Russian attacks on port and grain facilities in Ukraine which began over a month ago, have intensified in recent days, drawing condemnation from the UN’s top humanitarian official there.

Read the full story, “UN humanitarian chief in Ukraine condemns 'brutal and relentless' pattern of port attacks”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: UN humanitarian chief in Ukraine condemns 'brutal and relentless' pattern of port attacks

articles.description:
TOKYO, Japan, Sep 12 (IPS) -
 

1. SDGs and global governance

Sustainable development is the challenge of how to build a society in which humanity can live with dignity in this global environment. The SDGs set 17 goals and 169 targets to achieve sustainable development. Goals 16 and 17 are aimed precisely at building global governance through the formation of global rules. Goal 16 lists 10 specific targets, while Goal 17 lists 19 targets.

Read the full story, “The Perspective of Global Governance for Achieving the SDGs<br>From the viewpoint of sociology of domination.”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: The Perspective of Global Governance for Achieving the SDGs<br>From the viewpoint of sociology of domination.

articles.description:
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sep 12 (IPS) - While climate change is relentlessly progressing, threatening life on earth, world leaders continue to meet while planning for a future where this immense menace to human existence remains a minor item on the agenda.

Read the full story, “What Happens in the Arctic Does Not Stay in the Arctic”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: What Happens in the Arctic Does Not Stay in the Arctic

articles.description:
KAMPALA/LUSAKA/HARARE, Sep 12 (IPS) - Almost 30 years ago in 1994, the world witnessed a historic event as 179 nations convened on African soil, in Cairo, for the International Conference on Population and Development (ICPD).

Read the full story, “African Womens Reproductive Rights under Threat: Global Pushback Puts Lives at Risk”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: African Womens Reproductive Rights under Threat: Global Pushback Puts Lives at Risk

articles.description:
UNITED NATIONS, Sep 12 (IPS) - Everyone in this world is entitled to 15 minutes of fame-- is a legendary quote mis-attributed to the American pop icon Andy Warhol.

Over the years, the United Nations has laid down its own 15-minute rule for world leaders addressing the UN General Assembly.

Read the full story, “World Leaders Offered 15 Minutes of Fame at UNs High-Level Meeting”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: World Leaders Offered 15 Minutes of Fame at UNs High-Level Meeting

articles.author: Suzanne Kelly
articles.description:
EXPERT PERSPECTIVE — Today, as Western pundits and military experts monitor progress of the Ukrainian counteroffensive against Russia’s occupation forces in Southern Ukraine, many correctly [...] More 
The post The Argument for Adopting a Reagan Strategy in Ukraine appeared first on The Cipher Brief.
articles.title: The Argument for Adopting a Reagan Strategy in Ukraine
Turn Your Rising Home Equity Into Cash You Can Use
Dream Big with a Home Equity Loan
Want Cash Out of Your Home? Here Are Your Best Options

sources.title: World News Headlines, Latest International News, World Breaking News - Times of India

articles.description: Rescue teams have arrived from Egypt, Tunisia, the UAE, Turkiye and Qatar.
articles.title: Political fractures hinder global aid

articles.description: The coastal city of Derna in Libya experienced severe flooding after two dams burst, leaving thousands of people displaced and searching for loved ones. Many residents were caught off guard by the flooding as there were no evacuation plans in place. The devastation caused by the floodwaters resulted in the loss of lives and destruction of buildings.
articles.title: Caught unaware, whole families drowned in a matter of minutes

articles.description: Libyan authorities have called for an investigation into the cause of the devastating floods that have resulted in thousands of deaths in the country. The floods were triggered by a powerful storm that caused dams to burst, washing away buildings and trapping people inside. The death toll is estimated to be in the thousands, with many more people missing.
articles.title: Libya seeks answers as flood deaths feared to cross 20,000

articles.description: Nasa has released findings from its yearlong study into UFOs, stating that the study of these unidentified flying objects will require new scientific techniques and a shift in perception. The study's 33-page report cautions that the negative perception surrounding UFOs hampers data collection. NASA Administrator Bill Nelson aims to shift the conversation from sensationalism to science and reduce the stigma around UAPs (unidentified anomalous phenomena).
articles.title: Nasa says more science and less stigma are needed to understand UFOs

articles.description: The Pentagon has clarified that it has not restarted counterterrorism operations in Niger, despite earlier reports. Gen. James Hecker had stated that some manned aircraft and drone operations had resumed, but the Pentagon clarified that these missions were only for protecting US forces and not broader counterterrorism operations.
articles.title: Pentagon says surveillance flights, not counterterrorism ops, have restarted in Niger

articles.description: President Joe Biden challenged his Republican opponents by arguing that his management of the economy has been better than former President Donald Trump's. He accused Republicans of undermining working-class Americans and criticized their plans to cut taxes for the wealthy and make savings from Social Security, Medicare, and Medicaid.
articles.title: Joe Biden accuses Republicans of undercutting working-class Americans

articles.description: China conducted large-scale military drills in the Western Pacific, deploying an aircraft carrier and numerous naval ships and warplanes as a display of power against US pressure. The exercises took place after the U.S. conducted military drills with allies in the region. China's aircraft carrier, along with missile destroyers, frigates, and supply ships, were spotted in waters near Japan, Taiwan, and the Philippines.
articles.title: China conducts major military exercises in Western Pacific

articles.description: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is set to meet Elon Musk during his upcoming trip to the United States. The meeting, scheduled for Monday, will focus on discussions about artificial intelligence. This comes as Musk faces accusations of allowing antisemitic messages on his social media platform, X. The Anti-Defamation League has accused Musk of amplifying hate speech, but Musk has denied these claims.
articles.title: Israel's Benjamin Netanyahu is to meet Elon Musk. Their sit-down comes as X faces antisemitism controversy

articles.description: China has increased its military exercises near Taiwan, scrambling 68 military aircraft and sending 10 navy vessels into the area. The Chinese fleet, including the Shandong aircraft carrier, was detected about 60 nautical miles southeast of Taiwan. China claims Taiwan as its own territory and has been pressuring the island through military and political means.
articles.title: Taiwan detects 68 Chinese warplanes, 10 Navy vessels near island

articles.description: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is set to meet with billionaire Elon Musk during his upcoming trip to the United States. The agenda for the meeting has not been disclosed. However, Musk has recently faced accusations of allowing antisemitic messages on his social media platform, X.
articles.title: Israel's Netanyahu to meet Elon Musk as company faces antisemitism controversy

articles.description: Talks between the leaders of Serbia and Kosovo on improving ties failed to make a breakthrough Thursday, after Pristina rejected an EU compromise proposal, the bloc's foreign policy chief said. Kosovo insists it wants Serbia to make the first move by taking steps towards officially recognising its independence.
articles.title: EU fails to find breakthrough in Serbia, Kosovo talks

articles.description: The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) is set to announce new restrictions on the use of artificial intelligence (AI) technology. While the agency has successfully utilized AI in drug busts and crime prevention, DHS Secretary Alejandro Mayorkas stresses the importance of responsible and trustworthy use of AI that safeguards privacy, civil rights, and civil liberties.
articles.title: US Homeland Security Department reveals new AI guardrails as it deploys technology across agency

articles.description: The United Nations said Thursday that most of the thousands of deaths in Libya's flood disaster could have been averted if early warning and emergency management systems had functioned properly. If the system in Libya ad worked properly, "the emergency management forces would have been able to carry out the evacuation of the people, and we could have avoided most of the human casualties," WMO chief Petteri Taalas told reporters in Geneva.
articles.title: Most Libya flood casualties could have been avoided: UN

articles.description: Survivors of a migrant shipwreck off Greece in June have filed a lawsuit against the Greek authorities, accusing them of failing to protect the lives of those on board. The overcrowded fishing trawler, carrying between 400-750 people from Pakistan, Syria, and Egypt, sank in international waters. Only 104 men survived, and 82 bodies were recovered.
articles.title: Survivors of migrant shipwreck file lawsuit against Greek authorities

articles.description: A Palestinian family in Libya, who had fled Gaza during the 1967 Arab-Israeli war, has been affected by the devastating floods in the country. Two members of the Abu Amra family have died, and 12 others are missing after the storm caused dams to burst and destroyed a quarter of the city of Derna.
articles.title: Palestinian family that fled wars suffers deaths in Libya

articles.description: Israel's Finance Minister Bezalel Smotrich, a leader of the settlement movement, has taken steps to solidify Israel's control over the occupied West Bank. Smotrich has approved new settlement homes, legalized unauthorized outposts, and made it harder for Palestinians to build homes and move freely.
articles.title: Israel's finance minister now governs the West Bank. Critics see steps toward permanent control

articles.description: Firefighters in the United States are suing manufacturers and companies that make firefighting gear and foam, claiming that the gear contains toxic industrial compound PFAS, which is associated with health problems including cancer. Cancer has become the leading cause of death among firefighters, with the International Association of Fire Fighters attributing 66% of firefighter deaths between 2002 and 2019 to cancer.
articles.title: Firefighters fear the toxic industrial PFAS in the gear could be contributing to rising cancer cases

articles.description: Ten children were among the 56 people killed in a blaze in a Hanoi high-rise, police said on Thursday, which some residents desperately tried to escape by jumping out of upper stories, according to witnesses. Authorities have still not released the cause of the fire, which broke out just before midnight Tuesday and wasn't extinguished until Wednesday morning in the nine-story apartment building in Vietnam's capital.
articles.title: Witnesses say victims of a Hanoi high-rise fire jumped from upper stories to escape the blaze

articles.description: The city of Derna has buried thousands of people in mass graves, Libyan officials said Thursday, as search teams scoured ruins left by devastating floods and the city's mayor said that the death toll could triple or more. The deluge swept away entire families on Sunday night and exposed vulnerabilities in the oil-rich country that has been mired in conflict since its 2011 uprising.
articles.title: Libyan city buries thousands in mass graves after flood, while mayor says death toll could triple

articles.description: Taiwan has criticized Elon Musk for his comments on Taiwan being an integral part of China. The Taiwanese Foreign Ministry spokesman stated that Musk's blind flattery of China is not worthy of respect. Taiwan's foreign minister also suggested that Musk ask the Chinese Communist Party to open his platform, X, to the Chinese people.
articles.title: Taiwan slams Musk for calling it an 'integral part' of China

articles.description: Tech CEOs including Elon Musk, Mark Zuckerberg, and Sundar Pichai met with lawmakers to discuss AI regulation. Musk called for a US "referee" for AI to ensure safe use of the technology. Zuckerberg said Congress should engage with AI to support innovation and safeguards.
articles.title: Tech titans meet United States lawmakers, Elon Musk seeks 'referee' for artificial intelligence

articles.description: An Afghan soldier who escaped the Taliban and traveled through multiple countries before being detained at the Texas-Mexico border has been granted asylum in the United States. Abdul Wasi Safi, who feared being sent back to Afghanistan and killed by the Taliban, can now remain safely in the US
articles.title: Afghan soldier who was arrested at US-Mexico border after fleeing Taliban is granted asylum

articles.description: Brazil's high court opened the first trials Wednesday over the January 8 riots in Brasilia by supporters of far-right ex-president Jair Bolsonaro, who were demanding the ouster of his successor, Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva. Defense attorney Sebastiao Coelho da Silva called the trial "politically motivated."
articles.title: Brazil opens first trials over January 8 riots

articles.description: In what was hailed as a “momentous” move by Cambodia, the late American pipeline businessman George Lindemann’s family “voluntarily” agreed to return 33 looted artefacts to the Southeast Asian country. According to the US Attorney's Office, the artefacts that would be returned include statues of deities, angels and demons from the 10th and 12th centuries from Koh Ker.
articles.title: Family of late US billionaire George Lindemann agrees to return looted artefacts to Cambodia

articles.description: Vivek Ramaswamy joined a rising chorus of Republican presidential contenders in 2024 who have pledged to drastically cut the size and scope of the federal government if elected next year, calling for a "revolution" that will hold the federal bureaucracy "accountable."
articles.title: White House hopeful Ramaswamy joins Trump in calling for huge government job cuts

articles.description: White House press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre strongly criticized Republican plans to launch an impeachment inquiry against President Joe Biden. She denounced the effort as baseless and a political stunt, highlighting the lack of concrete evidence presented by Republicans. Jean-Pierre suggested that the initiative was driven by pressure from the far-right wing of the Republican Party and characterized the process as illegitimate.
articles.title: White House press secretary slams Republican impeachment inquiry against president Joe Biden as baseless

articles.description: A teenager in the United States was charged allegedly for trying to drown a black teen in a Cape Cod pond in Massachusetts. The black teen alleged that while John Sheeran (14) jabbed his head into the water, another white teen laughed and called him “George Floyd” as he couldn’t breathe.
articles.title: US teen, 14, charged of trying to drown Black youth in pond

articles.author: Omer Farooq Khan
articles.description: Pakistan President Arif Alvi has proposed November 6 as the date for the country's upcoming elections in a letter to the Chief Election Commissioner. The move has sparked controversy, as there are divided opinions among stakeholders on the timing of the polls. The president cited constitutional provisions giving him the authority to announce the poll date.
articles.title: Pakistan President Arif Alvi ‘advises’ EC to hold polls on Nov 6

articles.description: The White House denied Wednesday that the unfreezing of $6 billion of Iranian funds to help secure the release of five US citizens was effectively a ransom payment. It's not ransom," said White House national security spokesman John Kirby, pushing back against criticism of the deal.
articles.title: White House says Iran deal is 'not ransom'

articles.author: Omer Farooq Khan
articles.description: Imran Khan, the leader of the Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf (PTI) party, has had his judicial remand extended until September 26 in a cipher case. Khan and Shah Mahmood Qureshi, a former foreign minister, are accused of making public the contents of a confidential diplomatic cable. The cable was cited by Khan as proof of a US attempt to remove his government.
articles.title: Pakistan court extends Imran Khan’s remand in cipher case

articles.description: Former President Donald Trump dined with Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene and discussed the strategy for impeaching President Joe Biden. Trump has been closely following House Republicans' push for impeachment and has encouraged their efforts.Elise Stefanik, who briefed him on the impeachment inquiry strategy. However, Trump has not been pressuring House Speaker Kevin McCarthy regarding the impeachment inquiry into Biden.
articles.title: Trump has been privately encouraging GOP lawmakers to impeach Joe Biden

articles.description: Slovakia's Supreme Court has upheld a ruling dismissing a lawsuit by former Czech Prime Minister Andrej Babis against allegations of collaboration with the communist-era secret police. Babis had sued Slovakia's Institute of the Nation's Memory, which holds parts of his secret police files. The institute claims the files contain evidence that Babis was an agent, but he denies this.
articles.title: Former Czech Premier Andrej Babis loses case on collaborating with communist-era secret police

articles.description: Israeli air strikes on Wednesday killed two Syrian soldiers and wounded six others on Syria's west coast, state media said, quoting a military source. "At exactly 17:22 this afternoon, the Israeli enemy carried out strikes... from the direction of the Mediterranean Sea targeting some of our air defence sites in Tartus," the official news agency SANA quoted the source as saying.
articles.title: Israel strikes on Syria kill two soldiers: state media

articles.description: At least 5,100 people have been killed in the eastern Libyan city of Derna due to massive flooding caused by Mediterranean storm Daniel. The flooding, which was the result of two dams collapsing, has left thousands missing and tens of thousands homeless. Aid workers have struggled to reach the city due to washed-out roads, making it challenging to provide assistance to those affected.
articles.title: Death toll from devastating floods in Libyan city passes 5,100

articles.description: Brazil has officially requested assistance from US law enforcement in investigations involving former President Jair Bolsonaro. This comes after Bolsonaro's ex-aide, Mauro Cid, agreed to cooperate with Brazilian investigators. The request aims to corroborate Cid's statements regarding his involvement in various criminal probes, including falsified vaccination records and the sale of expensive jewels. Bolsonaro, who denies any wrongdoing, is facing mounting legal troubles after losing his re-election bid.
articles.title: Brazil requests US help for probes involving Bolsonaro, sources say

articles.description: A fishing vessel owned by Greenland's government will attempt to free a luxury cruise ship that ran aground in northwestern Greenland. The passengers and crew on the stranded ship are reported to be safe and doing well. The scientific fishing vessel will try to pull the cruise ship free during high tide. The cruise ship, MV Ocean Explorer, ran aground in Alpefjord in the Northeast Greenland National Park.
articles.title: A fishing vessel in Greenland will try to free a cruise ship that ran aground with 206 people

articles.description: Danelo Cavalcante, a convicted murderer who escaped from a Pennsylvania prison for two weeks, terrifying people in the suburbs west of Philadelphia, was apprehended on Wednesday,  Pennsylvania state police said. On August 31, he escaped from Chester County Prison, roughly 30 miles (50 kilometers) west of Philadelphia, by climbing between two walls that formed an extremely narrow corridor in the jail house yard and ascending onto the roof.
articles.title: Fugitive Danelo Cavalcante arrested after two weeks on the run

articles.description: A bushfire in central Australia is threatening the tourist town of Tennant Creek. Authorities have issued a "watch and act" alert for the region, indicating a heightened threat level. Tennant Creek, which is popular with travellers, is home to around 3,000 people. Changing wind conditions are posing a risk to residents, and the fire has breached containment lines to the north and south of the town.
articles.title: Huge bushfire raging in central Australia comes close to popular tourist town

articles.description: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un expressed his "full and unconditional support" to Russian President Vladimir Putin in Russia's "sacred fight" to defend its security interests, likely referring to the war in Ukraine. Kim also emphasized that North Korea's relationship with Russia is its top priority. The leaders met at a rocket launch facility in Siberia, highlighting their shared interests.
articles.title: North Korea's Kim vows full support for Russia’s 'sacred fight' after viewing launchpads with Putin

articles.description: Republican US representative Lauren Boebert was asked to leave a theater performance in Denver after causing disturbance by laughing, singing, recording, and vaping. She was escorted out along with another patron after receiving several complaints. Boebert confirmed the incident on social media, admitting to enjoying the performance and pleading guilty to laughing and singing too loudly. She denied vaping but admitted to taking a photo with her cellphone, unaware that photography was not permitted.
articles.title: US lawmaker Lauren Boebert kicked out of theatre for 'laughing, singing loudly'

articles.description: The US government has rejected former Twitter owner Elon Musk's request to end oversight of the company's data privacy and security practices. The government argues that Musk should not be immune to testifying about the company, as he has first-hand knowledge of the conduct being investigated.
articles.title: US says Musk should not be immune to testifying about the former Twitter

articles.description: China's arms exports have dropped by nearly a quarter in the last decade due to poor quality and inconsistent performance. The Chinese People's Liberation Army (PLA) is plagued by low-quality weapons. China's global market share has also shrunk. Buyers are attracted by the low prices, but they face hidden costs when the gear malfunctions.
articles.title: China's arms exports face sharp decline due to defective quality, unreliable performance: Analysts

articles.description: A court in Iraq has sentenced 18 police officers to jail terms of up to three years for failing to prevent protesters from storming and setting fire to Sweden's embassy in Baghdad. The attack on the embassy was in response to the desecration of the Quran by an Iraqi refugee in Stockholm. The court found the police officers guilty of not carrying out their duties and some of them were permanently disbarred from the force.
articles.title: 18 Iraq police get jail terms over Sweden embassy fire

articles.description: US House Speaker Kevin McCarthy is facing challenges from the far right within his own caucus, despite launching a formal probe into president Joe Biden. Hardline conservatives are pressuring McCarthy to include border security provisions and other conservative priorities in the upcoming spending measure to avoid a government shutdown.
articles.title: Kevin McCarthy faces threat as US House speaker despite impeachment move

articles.description: Hurricane Lee, a Category 3 storm, is expected to remain in open waters as it moves towards Atlantic Canada. It is located south of Bermuda and has winds of up to 115 mph. The storm is forecasted to weaken into a tropical storm and make landfall in Nova Scotia, Canada. Lee is generating dangerous surf and rip currents along the East Coast of the United States.
articles.title: Hurricane Lee swirls through open waters on a path toward Atlantic Canada

articles.description: The Department of Justice has accused Google of using its dominant position in the internet search market to stifle competition and innovation. The antitrust trial, the largest in the US in 25 years, will determine whether Google rigged the market in its favor by making its search engine the default choice on various devices and platforms.
articles.title: US claims Google pays more than $10 bn a year to maintain its search dominance

articles.description: North Korean leader Kim Jong-un arrived in Russia by private train for talks with president Vladimir Putin. The two delegations discussed joint tourism, agricultural projects, and deeper economic ties. Kim and Putin are expected to meet later this week. The make-up of Kim's delegation suggests an agenda heavy on defense industry cooperation.
articles.title: Kim Jong-un in Russia with military brass amid US warnings not to sell arms

articles.description: The US department of justice has accused Google of using its dominant position in the internet search market to stifle competition and hinder innovation. The department claims that Google rigged the market in its favor by making its search engine the default choice on various platforms and devices.
articles.title: It's United States vs Google in antitrust trial

articles.description: US Speaker Kevin McCarthy has directed top congressional Republicans to open an impeachment inquiry into President Biden. McCarthy wants three committees to carry out the inquiry, looking for evidence of financial wrongdoing or corruption. This is a break from McCarthy's previous stance, as he now believes a full House vote is unnecessary.
articles.title: House panel opens impeachment inquiry into Joe Biden over family business

articles.description: Torrential rains in Libya caused two dams to burst near the city of Derna, resulting in the deaths of over 5,000 people and leaving more than 10,000 missing. The storm, called Daniel, hit a country already divided by war and ill-prepared for such extreme weather conditions.
articles.title: 5,000 dead, 10,000 missing In Libya Floods

articles.author: Omer Farooq Khan
articles.description: Former Pakistani prime minister Shehbaz Sharif has announced that his brother, Nawaz Sharif, will return to Pakistan on October 21 to lead the party's political campaign for the upcoming elections. Nawaz Sharif was disqualified from holding public office in 2017 and has been in exile in London since then. Shehbaz Sharif expressed optimism that the country and economy will progress once again under his brother's leadership.
articles.title: Nawaz Sharif to return to Pakistan on October 21: Shehbaz Sharif

articles.author: Omar Farooq Khan
articles.description: Pakistan’s Supreme Court dismissed Tuesday pleas by two former army officers against convictions for plotting to overthrow the Benazir Bhutto-led government in 1995 and upheld their sentences. Colonels Mohammad Azad Minhas and Inayat Ullah Khan were arrested in September 1995 along with scores of others in the failed coup, sacked and sentenced to four years in 1996, with their properties confiscated.
articles.title: Pakistan SC upholds Benazir coup convictions, pleas by sacked army duo dismissed

articles.author: Omer Farooq Khan
articles.description: The Pakistani high court has reserved its verdict on a petition filed by former prime minister Imran Khan challenging the decision to conduct his trial in the cipher case at Attock jail. Imran Khan was sent to jail following his conviction in the Toshakhana graft case.
articles.title: Pak court reserves verdict on Imran Khan’s plea against cipher case trial in Punjab jail

articles.author: NAOMI CANTON
articles.description: After being regaled in India, UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak was heavily chastised by MPs in the House of Commons for failing to secure tougher language against Russia in the G20 leaders' declaration, as well as for leaving the UK out of a landmark new economic corridor agreement.
articles.title: UK PM Sunak roasted back home by MPs over ‘weak language’ in G20 declaration

articles.description: Morocco has been criticized for not accepting international aid following the devastating earthquake that struck the country on September 8. While Morocco accepted search-and-rescue teams from Spain, Qatar, the United Arab Emirates, and the UK, it did not take up offers of assistance from the United States, France, and other countries.
articles.title: Rescue teams are frustrated that Morocco did not accept more int'l help after quake

articles.description: US President Joe Biden's public approval rating edged up this month to its highest level since March, bolstered by support from members of his Democratic Party even as House Republicans launch a formal impeachment inquiry, a Reuters/Ipsos poll showed.The three-day poll, which ended on Sunday, showed a marginal increase in Biden's popularity from last month, when 40% of respondents said they approved of his performance since taking office in January 2021.
articles.title: Biden approval edges up to highest level since March

articles.description: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un arrived in Russia on Tuesday ahead of a meeting with President Vladimir Putin that the United States has warned could see an arms deal to support Moscow's assault on Ukraine.Making a rare foreign trip and his first since the pandemic, Kim was seen stepping onto a red-carpeted train platform before meeting Natural Resources Minister Alexander Kozlov.
articles.title: North Korea's Kim in Russia for Putin talks as US warns on arms deal

articles.description: The Polish government on Tuesday agreed to extend a ban on Ukrainian grain imports unilaterally even if the current EU restrictions expire on September 15. The statement said the government was still looking to extend the ban at the EU level but would do so in any case.
articles.title: Poland says will extend ban on Ukraine grain imports

articles.description: ISLAMABAD: Pakistan Muslim League-Nawaz (PML-N) supremo Nawaz Sharif will return to Pakistan from London on October 21 to lead the party's political c.
articles.title: Nawaz Sharif will return to Pakistan on October 21: Shehbaz Sharif

articles.author: Ishaan Tharoor
articles.description: Libya’s two regimes left critical infrastructure in a state of neglect. But the intervention of myriad outside powers laid the groundwork for disaster.
articles.title: Libya’s catastrophe is everyone’s fault

articles.author: Karen DeYoung
articles.description: The Biden administration is withholding an $85 million weapons financing package to Cairo over human rights concerns.
articles.title: U.S. cuts military aid to Egypt, sends money instead to Taiwan

articles.author: Bryan Pietsch, Annabelle Timsit, Adam Taylor, Mikhail Klimentov
articles.description: “Neither Elon Musk, nor any private citizen, can have the last word when it comes to U.S. national security,” said the chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee.
articles.title: Ukraine live briefing: Putin accepts Kim’s invitation to visit North Korea; Senate probing Starlink vulnerabilities

articles.author: Louisa Loveluck, Sarah Dadouch, Kareem Fahim
articles.description: A Washington Post team was among the first to reach the devastated city of Derna, in Libya’s flood-battered east, where the death toll could reach 20,000.
articles.title: In Libya’s flood-shattered east, a disaster of ‘mythic proportions’

articles.author: Widlore Mérancourt, Samantha Schmidt, Amanda Coletta
articles.description: The neighbors share the Caribbean island of Hispaniola and a long history of strained relations.
articles.title: Dominican Republic closes border with Haiti, further stoking tensions

articles.author: Les Carpenter
articles.description: Three months after raiding Paris 2024 headquarters, France’s top financial prosecutor says no significant corruption has been found in contract rigging investigation.
articles.title: No significant corruption found in Paris Olympic raid, prosecutor says

articles.description:
Images taken by satellite show the physical devastation from a flood that killed at least 11,300 people in the eastern Libyan city of Derna. 

Two dams above Derna burst early Monday under the pressure from rain dropped by a storm. The pent-up water swept blocks of low-lying downtown Derna out to the Mediterranean Sea. 

Many said they heard loud explosions as the dams exploded. A flood several meters (many feet) high rolled down a mountainside into the city. 

Images made about 400 miles above the earth’s surface show that the storm left a brown layer of mud and dirt across the city.

Untold numbers are buried under mud and debris that includes overturned cars and chunks of concrete. The death toll soared to 11,300 as search efforts continue, Marie el-Drese, secretary-general of the Libyan Red Crescent, told The Associated Press by phone Thursday.

She said that an additional 10,100 had been reported missing. Health authorities previously put the death toll in Derna at 5,500.

The...
articles.title: AP PHOTOS: Satellite images show flood devastation that killed more than 11,000 in Libya

articles.description:
Buildings destroyed after the earthquake on February 13, 2023, in Hatay, Turkey. | Murat Saka/dia images via Getty Images
    

  
Turkey is investigating and has arrested some contractors, but the entire political and economic system is implicated.
 Turkey is still in the middle of an emergency, reeling from the earthquake that killed at least 35,000 people last week. But the finger-pointing has already begun. 
The rush to punishment comes amid the grief, but also the mounting fury and frustration over the Turkish government’s earthquake response. Much of that is focused on the emergency response — waiting for aid and rescue teams — but it is also extending to anger about policies before the earthquake, about how shoddy building construction may have exacerbated the devastation of the dis…
articles.title: Who is responsible for Turkey’s bad buildings?

articles.description:
Getty Images
    

  
How we turned 20,000 Soviet nukes into zero-carbon energy — and how we can do the same with some of our own.
 Just a decade ago, one in 10 American lightbulbs was powered by dismantled Russian nuclear weapons.
That was made possible by the Megatons to Megawatts program, an agreement negotiated after the collapse of the Soviet Union to convert uranium from Russia’s nuclear weapons stockpile into fuel for US nuclear power plants. The unconventional policy was first proposed by MIT physicist Thomas Neff in a 1991 New York Times op-ed. By the time Megatons to Megawatts ran its full course from 1993 to 2013, it had eliminated about 20,000 nuclear warheads and stood out as a point of shared pride in the often jaded arms control and disarmament field. “Nearly every commercia…
articles.title: 10 years ago, we were turning nuclear bombs into nuclear energy. We can do it again.

articles.description:
Volunteers stand on rubble of a destroyed building in Kahramanmaras, Turkey, on February 7, 2023. | Adem Altan/AFP via Getty Images
    

  
What Turkey and Syria’s deadly earthquakes reveal about wealth.
 In the early hours of Monday, February 6, residents living in southern Turkey and northern Syria were woken by violent shaking, collapsing buildings, and sweeping blackouts. The earthquake buried residents in rubble and was followed by powerful aftershocks. By the following Monday, the death toll had passed 36,000 people. “It was like the apocalypse,” Abdul Salam al-Mahmoud, a resident of Atareb, Syria, told Reuters.  
The country is no stranger to quakes, having lost 17,000 people to a 7.4-magnitude tremor in 1999. But while last week’s earthquake was a 7.8-magnitude quake, and had an u…
articles.title: Why earthquakes are deadlier depending on where you live

articles.description:
A suspected Chinese spy balloon flies above Charlotte, North Carolina, on February 4, 2023.  | Peter Zay/Anadolu Agency via Getty Images
    

  
As all these objects fall, a new space race is rising.
 Now that the US military has shot down a suspected spy balloon from China and three other unidentified flying objects, there will be debates about the UFOs’ meaning, their capabilities, and why they were all up there in the first place. 
Though former CIA Director Michael Hayden said the initial balloon’s threat to the welfare of Americans was vastly inflated, others described the incident as a wake-up call. Former Trump national security adviser H.R. McMaster hopes it will lead to a “Sputnik moment,” harkening back to the US space race with the Soviet Union. The Wall Street Journal even war…
articles.title: Why the balloon and UFO affairs are a Sputnik moment

At night, we were forced to suspend work due to the high threat of repeated shelling," Klymenko said on the Telegram messaging app. Two missiles hit ...

articles.description: By Jake Spring BELEM, Brazil (Reuters) - Leaders from the eight Amazon rainforest countries are gathering on Tuesday for the first time in 14 years, with plans to reach a broad agreement on issues from fighting deforestation to financing sustainable development. The summit of Amazon Cooperation Treaty Organization (ACTO) members in the Brazilian city of Belem could agree to a regional pact to stop deforestation by 2030, end illegal gold mining, and cooperate on cross-border policing of environmental crime. Leaders are expected to announce the final agreement, known as the Belem Declaration, la...
articles.title: Amazon rainforest nations gather to forge shared policy in Brazil

articles.description: Georgian Prime Minister Irakli Garibashvili commemorated on Tuesday the victims of a brief war with Russia 15 years ago and lamented the loss of the breakaway regions of South Ossetia and Abkhazia. "This was a terrible tragedy," Garibashvili said on the anniversary of the start of the South Caucasus war, which lasted from August 8 to 12, 2008. He said 400 Georgians were killed and more than 2,000 injured. To this day, Moscow supports the breakaway Georgian regions of South Ossetia and Abkhazia and has stationed Russian troops in the region. Garibashvili said that the Black Sea republic was sti...
articles.title: Georgian premier marks 15-year anniversary of brief war with Russia

Heads of state from the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS) are preparing for a summit on Thursday to discuss their standoff with the junta, which defied an Aug. 6 deadline to reinstate ousted President Mohamed Bazoum. ECOWAS defence chiefs agreed on Friday on a possible m...
articles.title: Niger junta rebuffs latest diplomatic mission as high-stakes summit looms

articles.description: Kia is clearly serious about offering a top notch electric and it has unleashed the plush EV9 to prove it. After achieving a degree of success with the EV6 two years ago, the Koreans have upped the ante with an imposing and well-equipped EV9, albeit it at a high price. The first lavishly equipped Launch Edition with all-wheel drive will bend your bank balance to the tune of €83,190 in Europe. Prices for the base version with no gizmos hover around €70,000. The snub-nosed EV9 is big but not brutish. It stands at 5 metres from bumper to bumper in length and is designed to lure SUV buyers as well...
articles.title: Kia hits the big time with Range Rover-beating electric EV9

articles.author: Agence France-Presse
articles.description:
London-based sex worker Marin Scarlett and right-wing populist Nigel Farage might initially appear unlikely campaigning allies, but when it comes to the pitfalls of banking in Britain they share a common cause.
"It's ridiculous that financial institutions can act like moral arbiters," Scarlett told AFP, echoing Farage's exact same criticism last month after a scandal erupted around his treatment by British banks.
Farage's complaints about the closure of his account with the upmarket Coutts, a subsidiary of NatWest used by the late Queen Elizabeth II, dominated the news for days, prompted questions in parliament and cost top executives their jobs.
For Scarlett, who is in her thirties and started out as a sex worker 15 years ago, the sudden uproar was galling, given arbitrary account closure…
articles.title: 'Stigmatized': Sex workers join criticism of UK banks

articles.author: Agence France-Presse
articles.description:
The second-ranking US diplomat met Niger's military leaders on Monday to press to reverse a coup but reported no headway a day after an ultimatum from the West African bloc ECOWAS was ignored.
Victoria Nuland, a veteran envoy and acting deputy secretary of state, said she met for more than two hours with military chiefs who ousted democratically elected Western ally Mohamed Bazoum on July 26.
Nuland's trip, conducted in secrecy until she left, came after the expiration of a deadline set by ECOWAS to reinstate Bazoum by midnight (2300 GMT) on Sunday or risk military intervention.
The 15-nation bloc is reconvening for its own diplomatic push on the crisis with a summit Thursday in Nigerian capital Abuja.
A source close to ECOWAS said an immediate military intervention to restore Bazoum was n…
articles.title: US envoy meets Niger coup leaders but sees no headway

articles.author: Agence France-Presse
articles.description:
Mourners and fans gathered Tuesday in the Irish town once home to singer Sinead O'Connor to pay their last respects ahead of her burial.
The musician's funeral cortege will pass along the seafront in the town of Bray, 20 kilometers (13 miles) south of Dublin, where she lived for 15 years.
The Grammy award-winning singer, best known for her cover of "Nothing Compares 2 U", died last month after being found unresponsive at her London home. She was 56.
The musician, who rose to international fame in the 1990s, will be mourned at a funeral attended by family and friends before a private burial.
Her family offered the public the chance to pay their final respects by organizing the cortege through Bray, saying she loved the town and its residents.
"With this procession her family would like to a…
articles.title: Ireland bids farewell to singer Sinead O'Connor

articles.author: Reuters
articles.description:
ISLAMABAD (Reuters) — Pakistan's jailed former Prime Minister Imran Khan appealed against his conviction and three-year sentence on corruption charges on Tuesday, his lawyer said, a ruling which analysts say is likely to fuel political instability. 
Naeem Panjutha said the petition challenging the weekend conviction had been filed in Islamabad High Court which will hear the case on Wednesday. Ex-cricketer Khan, 70, was jailed on charges of selling state gifts unlawfully during his tenure as premier from 2018 to 2022.
articles.title: Jailed ex-Pakistan PM Imran Khan challenges graft conviction

articles.author: Miami Herald
articles.description: As a kidnapped American nurse and her child marked their 11th day in captivity in Haiti on Monday, the United Nations’ leading child-welfare agency says it is seeing an alarming spike in the abductions of women and children in the Caribbean nation. Nearly 300 cases have been reported in the first six months of this year, UNICEF said. The number is close to the total documented in 2022 and is close to three times more than what was recorded in 2021. In Haiti, most kidnappings are at the hands of armed gangs, whose warfare has worsened since the 2021 assassination of the country’s president, Jov...
articles.title: Kidnappings of women, children spiking in Haiti where a US nurse, daughter remain captive

articles.author: Reuters
articles.description: By Claudia Martini and Miguel Lo Bianco BUENOS AIRES (Reuters) - Argentines, who have seen jobs and wages hit by economic malaise and rampant inflation, lined up at churches on Monday to ask St. Cayetano, the patron saint of bread and labor, for employment, with some critical of politicians for not doing enough to help. The South American country, which saw unemployment tick up to 6.9% in the first quarter, is set for primary elections on Sunday where the conservative opposition is expected to outperform the ruling Peronist coalition. The run-up to the vote, in effect a dress rehearsal for the...
articles.title: Hard-hit Argentina workers ask saints, not politicians, for jobs

articles.author: Agence France-Presse
articles.description:
Crouching beside Ukrainian-made attack drones on a runway, TV star Serhiy Prytula appeared keen to taunt Moscow with a crowdfunded fleet that experts have linked with recent strikes inside Russia.
Ukraine has not taken direct responsibility for the string of attacks, including on the capital Moscow, but President Volodymyr Zelensky has warned that "war" is coming to Russia.
Polls show the former stand-up comedian's crowdfunding campaigns for the military have rendered him one of the country's most trusted public figures -- second only to Zelensky.
Offering a rare glimpse at Ukraine's homegrown explosive drones, Prytula recently shared images of himself with a fleet in an undisclosed location.
"Muscovites! Shudder from the sirens. Go to the bomb shelters," he wrote on social media alongside…
articles.title: 'From Ukrainians without love': Drone fundraiser taunts Moscow

articles.author: Common Dreams
articles.description:
Local, national, and global leaders warned of the dangers of nuclear weapons as they commemorated the 78th anniversary of the dropping of an atomic bomb on the city of Hiroshima Sunday.
This year's anniversary comes as the release of the film Oppenheimer has offered a high-profile reminder of the history of the atomic bomb and as nuclear tensions in the current day have heightened, in part due to Russia's invasion of Ukraine. At the start of the year, the Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists moved their doomsday clock to 90 seconds to midnight.
"Leaders around the world must confront the reality that nuclear threats now being voiced by certain policymakers reveal the folly of nuclear deterrence theory," Hiroshima Mayor Kazumi Matsui said during his peace address at the commemoration ceremony …
articles.title: On 78th anniversary of Hiroshima bombing, mayor decries 'folly' of deterrence theory

articles.author: Agence France-Presse
articles.description:
Organisers of the World Scout Jamboree asked host South Korea Monday to "urgently" evacuate tens of thousands of children from their campsite ahead of a typhoon, just days after a heatwave caused mass scout illnesses.
Typhoon Khanun, which killed at least two people in Japan, is due to make landfall in South Korea on Thursday, near where some 43,000 scouts have been camping in North Jeolla province for their problem-plagued jamboree.
Korean media have called the jamboree "a national disgrace" after an extreme heatwave caused hundreds of scouts to fall ill and prompted American and British scout groups to withdraw as criticism grew over conditions at the campsite.
Organisers had insisted the event would continue but on Monday the World Organization of the Scout Movement said Seoul had told …
articles.title: After heatwave, typhoon forces South Korea to evacuate scout jamboree

articles.author: Agence France-Presse
articles.description:
More than 3,000 US military personnel have arrived in the Red Sea aboard two warships, as part of increased deployments after tanker seizures by Iran, the US Navy said Monday.
The US sailors and Marines entered the Red Sea on Sunday after transiting through the Suez Canal in a pre-announced deployment, the US Navy's Fifth Fleet said in a statement.
They arrived on board the USS Bataan and USS Carter Hall warships, providing "greater flexibility and maritime capability" to the Fifth Fleet, the statement added.
The US military says Iran has either seized or attempted to take control of nearly 20 internationally flagged ships in the region over the past two years.
USS Bataan is an amphibious assault ship which can carry fixed-wing and rotary aircraft as well as landing craft. The USS Carter H…
articles.title: Thousands of US sailors, Marines reach Red Sea after Iran tensions

articles.description:
There are fears up to 20,000 people have died after flooding through eastern Libya. 

Hope is turning to despair for residents in the city of Derna as survivors continue to wade through the rubble in search of loved ones.

Questions are being raised about what could have been done to prevent the loss of life.

Satellite images from before and after the floods show the levels of immense destruction.

The hostilities in recent years have split the city into sections as rescue crews face a difficult task of bringing relief to as many places as possible.
articles.title: Libya floods death toll rises above 20,000 as survivors continue searching

articles.description:
At least 56 people, including children, have died in an apartment building fire in Vietnam's capital Hanoi.

Rescue efforts have been hampered due to the building not having emergency exits and being positioned at the end of a narrow alley.

At least 70 people were rescued and nearly 40 people were injured when they jumped onto neighbouring roofs to escape the inferno.

Firefighters extinguished the fire in about an hour, as footage shows the intense blaze shooting out from every floor of the building.

Vietnam's Prime Minister visited the site to extend his condolences and police have detained the building's owner ahead of further investigation.
articles.title: At least 56 dead following nine-floor apartment inferno in Hanoi

articles.description:
Former ADF personnel could face up to 20 years behind bars if they work for foreign military bodies without approval.

New legislation is set to be introduced by Defence Minister Richard Marles which will prevent sensitive defence information from being accessed by foreign militaries.

It follows revelations Beijing was seeking to poach former Australian pilots to train its military last year.

The Chinese recruitment scheme reportedly extended to using third parties for headhunting Western military leaders.  

Those working within the Five Eyes countries, the US, UK, New Zealand and Canada, will be exempt from the tough new rules.
articles.title: Tough new laws for unsanctioned ADF personnel working with foreign military bodies

articles.description:
The Australian’s Washington correspondent Adam Creighton says US President Joe Biden’s impeachment inquiry will be “a lot more focused” on one single question from the Biden family dealings. 

Mr Creighton joined Sky News Australia host Paul Murray to talk about the “perfectly justified” impeachment inquiry into the President on corruption claims. 

“We have known about the suspicion of corruption in relation to Ukraine for some time,” he said.

“Then of course we had Hunter Biden’s laptop and all the emails about ’10 per cent for the big guy’, so there has been a lot of smoke there. 

“Biden lied – that’s the big one … he has been saying over and over he knew nothing about his son’s business dealings.

“For the Democrats, it is bad – he is going to have the pall of impeachment hanging over him as he campaigns for re-election.”
articles.title: ‘A lot of smoke’: ‘Pall of impeachment’ hanging over Joe Biden

articles.description:
North Korea's leader Kim Jong Un will meet with Russian President Vladimir Putin at an unspecified location in Russia’s Far East region later in the week.

Kim Jong Un arrived in Russia on board a heavily armoured train yesterday ahead of his meeting with the Russian president.

Vladimir Putin is currently attending the Eastern Economic Forum in Vladivostok which is Russia’s closest city to the North Korean border.

North Korea Political Expert Dr Leonid Petrov believes the meeting between the meeting is significant for both parties and gives Russia the chance to demonstrate its new diplomatic ambition following its invasion of Ukraine.

“Russia has been increasingly isolated and … it’s important to demonstrate that he (Vladimir Putin) is not just someone who is now being sought by the International Criminal Court but also supported by the neighbouring states like North Korea.”
articles.title: Russia to show new diplomatic ambitions ahead of talks with North Korea’s Kim Jong Un

Both groups claim, either explicitly or implicitly, that American B-61 gravity bombs and the nuclear sharing arrangement as a whole are militarily obsolete and lack credibility. However, participants in the ongoing debate about the future of NATO’s nuclear deterrence posture have failed to realize that the technological and political nature of nuclear sharing is changing. The F-35A Lightning II, which is set to replace current legacy

articles.author: Dave Maxwell
articles.description:
The OSS Society's William J. Donovan Award® Dinner

            
The OSS Society's William J. Donovan Award® Dinner, the preeminent annual gathering of the US intelligence and Special Operations communities, will be held in Washington, DC, on October 21, 2023. Corporate sponsorships are still available. Please click on this link to download the invitation: https://www.dropbox.com/scl/fi/didrkh4z4mpxkl5xkak5p/2023_Invite_FINAL.pdf?rlkey=sxg1ya3r2yixch9lkoo44a723&dl=0. 
The OSS Society offers a $100 discount to OSS Society members who register online. (To become a member of The OSS OSS Society, please fill out its membership application form: https://www.osssociety.org/forms.html.) Former military personnel receive a discounted ticket price, too. Here's a link to register online: https://conta.cc/3DQhcRM.
 

 

      Dave Maxwell
Wed, 09/13/2023 - 8:57am

Read more about The OSS Society's William J. Donovan Award® Dinner
articles.title: The OSS Society's William J. Donovan Award® Dinner

“We are totally back,” said Steven Soutendijk, executive managing director at Cushman & Wakefield.
Retailers around Midtown office corridors “live and die with office density, and we’re seeing a noticeable difference,” said David LaPierre, vice president of CBRE.
Now, there doesn’t seem to be a shortage of old and new concepts.
“It’s like the city and retailers have woken up,” said Jared Epstein, president and chief executive of Aurora Capital Associates.  “We had stock on just about everything from Soho to the Meatpacking District, West Village, Midtown and Brooklyn.  There’s clothing, food, fitness, healthcare, and interest at every level, with spaces filling up fast.

articles.description:
Axios: Favorite Biden columnist: He "should not run again in 2024" 
President Biden, befitting his generation, loves newspapers and the classic columnists. David Ignatius, Tom Friedman and David Brooks top his list.

 
Driving the news: Ignatius, 73, a well-wired Washington Post foreign-affairs columnist who writes spy novels on the side, is out with a column (page A23 Wednesday) with the blunt headline: "President Biden should not run again in 2024."

 
Why it matters: Biden, 80, still sees himself as a young go-getter. Here's a respected voice he has known for 40+ years telling him that by plunging ahead, he "risks undoing his greatest achievement — which was stopping Trump."

 
Read more ....

 
Update #1: WaPo columnist argues Biden 'too old' to run again, should have stopped Hunter's 'attempts to impress clients' (FOX News)
 
Update #2: More Voices Call On Biden To Withdraw From The 2024 Race (Moon of Alabama)

 
WNU Editor: When you are a Democrat President and you lose David Ignatius. Yup .... you are in trouble.
Update #3: The poll numbers are certainly troubling (see below).

Just 28% of Americans think Biden inspires confidence, down 24% from two years ago or 7% from five months ago.
According to a CNN poll, only 26% believe "he has the stamina and determination to serve" as president pic.twitter.com/4lboXi09UK
— Sprinter (@Sprinter99800) September 10, 2023
articles.title: US President Biden's Favourite Columnist Says He "Should Not Run Again In 2024"

As predicted by a number of independent geopolitical commentators, including ourselves, the emerging official narrative on why Ukraine's counteroffensive ended in failure will be to falsely claim the West didn't provide "enough" weapons in a timely fashion. Despite the literally tens of billions of US taxpayer dollars sunk into Kiev's war effort at record-breaking pace and scale, it will be the "fault" of the United States and its allies—or at least this will be solidified as the Ukrainian government's perspective and narrative (and then will be parroted among Zelensky's most diehard hawkish supporters). 
Read more ....

WNU Editor: Desperate people do desperate things. And they are some in Ukraine who are starting to grow more and more desperate. But to directly strike Europe if the West curtails their support? I doubt that this will happen.

Reuters: China becomes first to name new Afghan ambassador under Taliban 
KABUL (Reuters) - China became the first country on Wednesday to formally name a new ambassador to Afghanistan since the Taliban takeover, after its envoy presented credentials at a ceremony in Kabul. 
The Taliban have not been officially recognized by any foreign government, and Beijing did not indicate whether Wednesday's appointment signaled any wider steps towards formal recognition of the Taliban.

 
Read more ....

 
WNU Editor: China has yet to formally recognize the Taliban government. But this is a first step towards a formal recognition by China that the Taliban are the legitimate rulers of Afghanistan.

Taiwan's Kinmen is located adjacent to the Chinese city of Xiamen [File: Ann Wang/Reuters]

 
Al Jazeera: China unveils ‘special’ measures to boost Taiwan’s access to coastal Fujian

 
Beijing has proposed transforming Fujian province into a zone for integrated development with Taiwan. 
China will take a number of “special” policy measures to improve access for Taiwanese enterprises to Fujian province across the Taiwan Strait, the Chinese state planner has announced, under a long-term cross-strait integrated development plan. 
China will deepen the integrated development of the Chinese city of Xiamen and Taiwan-controlled Kinmen islands, including the acceleration of gas, electricity and transportation links between the two, said Cong Liang, vice chairman of the National Development and Reform Commission, on Thursday.

 
Read more ....

 
WNU Editor: I lived and worked in this part of China in the 1980s. This is an idea that China (and some in Taiwan) have been pushing for decades. 
Update: Taiwan is saying no .... Taiwan rejects China's integrated development plan as politicised cash grab (Reuters). 
China Proposes A Plan To Boost Taiwan’s Access To Coastal Fujian

 
Fujian, Taiwan to enjoy closer bond as mainland unveils integration plan -- CGTN

LBC: ‘Russia expects this war to go on for some time’: North Korea meeting shows Putin ‘playing long game’, ex-MI6 spy says 
Vladimir Putin's meeting with North Korean leader Kim Jon Un shows Russia is planning to "hunker down" for a long war in Ukraine, a former MI6 spy has told LBC. 
Speaking after Kim Jong Un arrived in Russia ahead of a meeting with Mr Putin, the former head of MI6's Russia desk told LBC's Andrew Marr there is "serious intent" behind the meeting.
"The Russians are now indicating they expect this war [in Ukraine] to go on for a long time and in fact, that may well be what lies behind their meeting with Kim Jong Un today," Christopher Steele told LBC.

WNU Editor: Talked to my cousin who lives in Moscow last night. He has a lot of military experience, and his opinion is that this war is going to go on into 2026.

Prague Monitor: Czechia Will Not Deport Ukrainian Deserters to Kiev 
Ukraine’s attempt to extradite refugees who sought shelter in the Czech Republic to avoid conscription is expected to face significant hurdles through official channels. Such a request would likely contravene Czech law, making it impossible for Justice Minister Pavel Blažek (ODS) to approve it, as confirmed by the Justice Ministry to Echo24.
The Ukrainian military is currently launching a counter-offensive to regain territories occupied by Russian forces, requiring a substantial manpower. However, even amidst pervasive corruption, there remains a shortage of recruits. Some Ukrainian men have managed to evade military service by leaving the country with the assistance of bribes, potentially numbering in the tens of thousands.

 
Read more ....

 
WNU Editor: Five European countries have already made the decision to not extradite Ukrainians who have escaped mobilization .... Already five European countries have refused to extradite men who have escaped mobilization to Ukraine (MIND).
articles.title: Czech Republic Will Not Deport Ukrainian Deserters To Kiev

Zero Hedge: Trans Spox Says Ukraine Will Hunt Down "Russian Propagandists" Around The World 
Sarah Ashton-Cirillo, the transgender ex-journalist from the US who is now a spokesperson for Ukraine's Territorial Defense Forces, has issued yet another bizarre and unhinged statement on behalf of the Ukrainian military. 
The military spokesperson is vowing that Russia's "propagandists" will be "hunted down" in a message which was published days ago, but which is now going viral and being mocked. 
Ashton-Cirillo said in the clip, "Next week, the teeth of the Russian devils will gnash ever harder, and their rabid mouths will foam an uncontrollable frenzy as the world will see a favorite Kremlin propagandist pay for their crimes."

 
Read more ....

 
WNU Editor: It is bad enough that everyone who is still in Ukraine must keep their negative opinions on the Zelensky regime to themselves or they may face certain consequences. But Kyiv's threats to now strike against those who voice a different opinion in another country is raising the conflict to another level. But what is even more disturbing is the "sound of silence" from Western governments and the Western media on these threats from the Zelensky government to attack citizens in another country.
articles.title: Ukraine Says It Will Hunt Down "Russian Propagandists" Around The World

articles.description:
DNYUZ/New York Times: Russia Overcomes Sanctions to Expand Missile Production, Officials Say 
Russia has managed to overcome sanctions and export controls imposed by the West to expand its missile production beyond prewar levels, according to U.S., European and Ukrainian officials, leaving Ukraine especially vulnerable to intensified attacks in the coming months. 
In addition to spending more than $40 billion providing weapons for Ukraine, the United States has made curbing Russia’s military supply a key part of its strategy to support Kyiv. 
As a result of the sanctions, American officials estimate that Russia was forced to dramatically slow its production of missiles and other weaponry at the start of the war in February 2022 for at least six months. But by the end of 2022, Moscow’s military industrial manufacturing began to pick up speed again, American officials who spoke on condition of anonymity to disclose the sensitive assessment now concede.

 
Read more ....

 
WNU Editor: So much for the Western political and media narrative that we have been hearing constantly for the past year that Russia was going to run out of missiles. 
On a side note. 
The above New York Times post reveals something that should give everyone pause .... 
 .... it costs a Western country $5,000 to $6,000 to make a 155-millimeter artillery round, whereas it costs Russia about $600 to produce a comparable 152-millimeter artillery shell. 
 You cannot win a war if the economies of production favors your opponent.
articles.title: Russia's Missile Production is Now Beyond Prewar Levels

Politico.eu: Shock and recriminations as Chinese spy scandal rocks UK parliament

 
Rishi Sunak under pressure to toughen stance on Beijing. 
 LONDON — Rishi Sunak has spent most of his brief premiership treading a delicate balance on relations with China. So the last thing the British prime minister needed as he enters a careful autumn of diplomacy was a Chinese spy scandal erupting in his midst. 
Westminster is this week reeling from the news that a British citizen working as a parliamentary researcher for MPs is under arrest on suspicion of spying for Beijing. 
Two men, one in his 20s and another in his 30s, were arrested under the Official Secrets Act in March, police confirmed, after the news was reported in the Sunday Times. 

 
Read more ....

articles.description:
USAF

 
Warzone/The Drive: B-21 Raider Seen Like Never Before In New Images

 
We have just been given our first side view of Northrop Grumman’s B-21 Raider stealth bomber, an aircraft that remains cloaked in secrecy.  
During Air Force Chief of Staff Charles Q. Brown's speech at this year's Air & Space Forces Association's mega conference outside of Washington, D.C., the soon-to-be Chairman of the Joint Chiefs dropped two new images of the B-21 Raider. While the stealth bomber was rolled out in December of last year, it remains cloaked in secrecy. Brown, the top Air Force uniformed officer, didn't specifically reference the images in his presentation. 
Up until today, only one angle of the full aircraft has been seen by the public — head-on — and in a very controlled environment at the bomber's unveiling. Aside from a close-up of the cockpit area at an angle, all imagery published since then has been from the same head-on perspective, although it has progressively shown the aircraft in more detail. Now we have our first quartering view of the flying-wing jet, which provides significant details about its design. A new head-on image also gives us a better idea of the bomber's actual size. Both images were taken at Northrop Grumman's facility at Plant 42 in Palmdale, California. 

 
Read more .... 
New Images Emerge Of The B-21

 
CSAF Shows Off New Images of the B-21; Raider Begins Engine Runs -- Air & Space Forces

New B-21 photos released, as engine runs begin -- Breaking Defense
 
New Photos Offer Rare Glimpse at US' Classified B-21 Stealth Bomber -- Sputnik
articles.title: New Images Emerge Of The B-21

France 24: Putin and Kim Jong Un meet in Russian Far East

 
Vladimir Putin and Kim Jong Un are engaged in talks over North Korea's space program and the political situation in Asia and Europe. The visit is Kim's first with a world leader since Pyongyang shut down over COVID-19. 
North Korean leader Kim Jong Un met with Russian President Vladimir Putin Wednesday for a day of talks that began at the Vostochny Cosmodrome in Russia's Far East.
The two leaders were at a remote Siberian rocket launch site, and began the day by inspecting a Soyuz-2 space facility.

Later, the two lavished one another with compliments during a state dinner. 
Read more ....

articles.title: Putin and Kim Jong Un Meet At The Vostochny Cosmodrome In Russia's Far East

articles.description:
BBC: Ukraine launches missile attack on Crimea 
Russia says Ukraine has launched 10 missiles and three unmanned boats in an attack on the home of its Black Sea fleet in Crimea. 
The attack caused a large fire at a Sevastopol shipyard which left 24 people injured, Russia said. 
Moscow-installed governor Mikhail Razvozhayev claimed most of the weapons were intercepted but that two ships had been damaged. 
Ukraine has strongly implied western-supplied cruise missiles were used.
Unmanned vessels, known by many different names including sea drones and drone boats, operate on or below the water. 
They usually have built-in explosives and cameras that feed directly back to the person controlling them.

 
Read more ....

 
WNU Editor: This attack happened on the same day that Putin was meeting Nor…
articles.title: Ukraine Launch Massive Missile Attack On Sevastapol

RT: German-made drone used to attack Russia – media 
Ukraine has reportedly deployed an unmanned aerial vehicle produced by Bavaria’s Quantum-Systems 
Ukrainian forces have reportedly utilized a German-made drone on Russian soil for the first time, deploying the unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) in a failed attack in Bryansk Region. 
A mid-range Vector drone, made by Quantum-Systems, was shot down on Sunday during an attempted attack in the Novozybkov district, according to a report by Russian online media outlet Mash. The report didn’t identify the intended target.

 
Read more ....

A training exercise in Poland in May this year. Nato is pushing to transform itself from crisis response to a war-fighting alliance, prompted by the invasion of Ukraine © Artur Widak/NurPhoto/Reuters 

 
Zero Hedge: NATO Prepares For Biggest Military Exercise Since Cold War, And Close To Russia 
The upcoming Steadfast Defender NATO war drills, set for early 2024, are expected to be the biggest military exercises in Europe since the end of the Cold War, the Financial Times is reporting Monday. 
At a moment the war in Ukraine grows more and more unpredictable, given neither Russia nor the West have shown any signs of backing down, the FT writes that "Nato is preparing its biggest live joint command exercise since the cold war next year, assembling more than 40,000 troops to practice how the alliance would attempt to repel Russian aggression against one of its members." 
Read more ....
Update #1: Nato to launch biggest military exercise since cold war (Financial Times)
 
Update #2: NATO in 2024 to conduct biggest military exercise since Cold War in Germany, Poland, Baltics (The New Voice of Ukraine)

 
WNU Editor: Conducting massive military exercises on the border of a country that is already at war. What could go wrong?
articles.title: NATO Preparing For The Biggest Military Exercises In Europe Since The Cold War

articles.description:
NATO: NATO navies hold annual Northern Coasts collective defence exercise in the Baltic Sea 
Some 30 warships and 3,200 personnel from 14 nations will participate in the annual two-week naval exercise Northern Coasts, which starts on Saturday (9 September 2023) in the Baltic Sea, primarily off the coasts of Estonia and Latvia. Led by the German Navy, Northern Coasts is one of the biggest exercises in the region, and is focusing for the first time on high-end warfare and the collective defence of NATO Allies. 

 
Read more ....

 
Update: NATO Baltic War Games Simulate Article 5 Collective Defense War With Russia (Zero Hedge)

 
WNU Editor: Apparently this is the first time these type of exercises are being held .... NATO to Conduct First Major Drills Focused on Repelling Russian Attacks (Defense Post).
articles.title: NATO Conducting Major Baltic Exercises Focused On Repelling Russian Attacks

FOX News: McCarthy to green light Biden impeachment inquiry this week 
McCarthy will tell House Republicans impeachment inquiry against Biden is the 'logical next step' for their investigations 
Fox News Digital has confirmed House Speaker Kevin McCarthy, R-Calif., will tell House Republicans today that beginning an impeachment inquiry against President Biden is "the logical next step." 
The House GOP conference plans to hold a meeting on Thursday morning for key committee chairs to lay out their latest findings and the status of the investigations into the Biden family.
House Judiciary Committee Chairman Rep. Jim Jordan, R-Ohio, and House Oversight Committee Chairman Rep. James Comer, R-Ky., are expected to lead Thursday's meeting. 

 
Read more ....

articles.description:
OPEC Oil Data Show 3 Million-Barrel Shortfall on Saudi Supply Squeeze

 
Bloomberg: OPEC Oil Data Show 3 Million-Barrel Shortfall on Saudi Supply Squeeze 
Global oil markets face a supply shortfall of more than 3 million barrels a day next quarter — potentially the biggest deficit in more than a decade — as Saudi Arabia extends its production cuts.
The latest data published by OPEC show why the kingdom’s supply squeeze, amid a period of record demand, has sent oil prices surging beyond $90 a barrel in London. Riyadh announced last week it will extend an extra 1 million-barrel-a-day output reduction until the end of the year, even though markets are already tightening. 
World oil inventories, having depleted sharply this quarter, are set for an even steeper drop of roughly 3.3 million barrels a day in the next three months, forecasts published in a report from the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries indicated on Tuesday. 
Read more ....

 
Update: Oil sprints higher as OPEC report reveals Saudi Arabia cuts further (FXStreet)

 
WNU Editor: Pray for a warm winter.
articles.title: Expect Higher Oil And Gas Prices This Winter

articles.description:
BBC: US releases $6bn in frozen Iran funds for prisoner swap 
The US has issued a sanctions waiver for banks to transfer $6bn (£4.8bn) of frozen Iranian funds from South Korea to Qatar, paving the way for the release of five Americans held by Iran.

Secretary of State Antony Blinken told Congress that the money would provide "limited benefit" to Iran as it could only be used for humanitarian trade. 
He also confirmed that five Iranians detained in the US would be freed as part of the prisoner exchange deal.

Republicans condemned the transfer.

One senator accused President Joe Biden of paying a "ransom to the world's worst state sponsor of terrorism".

 
Read more ....

 
WNU Editor: Iran's President has already said what he is going to do with the money .... Iranian president reveals plans for spending $6 billion gained in US prisoner exchange (FOX News). 
Needless to say. Republicans are furious .... Cotton: Biden’s decision to release $6 billion in frozen Iranian funds ‘shameful’ (The Hill). more here .... Donald Trump Rages at US Paying '6 Billion Dollars for Hostages' (Newsweek).
